meanings.def: to move forward on your hands and knees or with your body close to the ground
examples: Our baby is just starting to crawl.
A man was crawling away from the burning wreckage.
She crawled under the fence.
As night fell, we managed to crawl back to our lines.
Has the baby started to crawl yet?
We spent an hour crawling around on our hands and knees looking for the key.
She was forced to crawl along through the thickening mist.

meanings.def: when an insect, a spider, etc. crawls, it moves forward on its legs
examples: There's a spider crawling up your leg.
The traffic was crawling along.
The weeks crawled by.
The traffic was crawling as I left the city.
The taxi crawled to a halt.

meanings.def: to be too friendly or helpful to somebody in authority, in a way that is not sincere, especially in order to get an advantage from them
examples: She's always crawling to the boss.

meanings.def: if you say that somebody comes/crawls out of the woodwork, you mean that they have suddenly appeared in order to express an opinion or to take advantage of a situation
examples: When he won the lottery, all sorts of distant relatives came out of the woodwork.

meanings.def: to make you feel afraid or full of horror
examples: Just the sight of him makes my skin crawl.

idioms.def: if you say that somebody comes/crawls out of the woodwork, you mean that they have suddenly appeared in order to express an opinion or to take advantage of a situation
examples: When he won the lottery, all sorts of distant relatives came out of the woodwork.

idioms.def: to make you feel afraid or full of horror
examples: Just the sight of him makes my skin crawl.
The traffic slowed to a crawl.
The traffic was moving at a slow crawl.
Westbound traffic was down to a crawl.

meanings.def: a fast swimming stroke that you do lying on your front moving one arm over your head, and then the other, while kicking with your feet
examples: a swimmer doing the crawl
He struck out across the pool in a powerful crawl.
